member.name: N:Devart.Data.SQLite
member.summary: This namespace contains classes with provider-specific functionality.

member.name: T:Devart.Data.SQLite.AutoVacuumMode
member.summary: Determines the auto-vacuum flag in the database.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.AutoVacuumMode.Full
member.summary: The "freelist" pages are moved to the end of the file and the file is truncated to remove the freelist pages at every commit.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.AutoVacuumMode.Incremental
member.summary: A separate incremental_vacuum pragma must be invoked to cause the vacuum to occur.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.AutoVacuumMode.None
member.summary: Unused database file pages are added to a "freelist" are reused for subsequent inserts. The database file does not shrink. This is the default mode.

member.name: T:Devart.Data.SQLite.EncryptionMode
member.summary: Determines whether the database is encrypted and kind of the database encryption.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.EncryptionMode.CEROD
member.summary: The SQLite database uses the CEROD encryption. The SQLite Compressed and Encrypted Read-Only Database (CEROD) Extension is an add-on to the public domain version of SQLite that allows an application to read compressed and encrypted database files in addition to ordinary SQLite database files. Password from the ConnectionString is used for the database.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.EncryptionMode.None
member.summary: The SQLite database is not encrypted.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.EncryptionMode.SEE
member.summary: The SQLite database uses the SEE encryption. The SQLite Encryption Extension (SEE) is an add-on to the public domain version of SQLite that allows an application to read and write encrypted database files. Password from the ConnectionString is used for the database. For more information about SEE see the SQLite Encryption Extension web page.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.EncryptionMode.SQLCipher
member.summary: The SQLite database uses the SQLCipher encryption. SQLCipher is an open source extension to SQLite that provides transparent 256-bit AES encryption of database files. Password from the ConnectionString is used for the database. For more information about SEE see the SQLCipher web page.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.EncryptionMode.SQLiteCrypt
member.summary: The SQLite database uses the SQLiteCrypt encryption. The SQLiteCrypt is an add-on to the public domain version of SQLite that adds transparent AES 256 encryption support for SQLite. In order to connect to such a database, you need to set the Password and SQLiteCrypt License Key connection string parameters.

member.name: T:Devart.Data.SQLite.JournalMode
member.summary: Determines the journal mode for database.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.JournalMode.Default
member.summary: SQLite default Journal Mode is used.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.JournalMode.Delete
member.summary: In the Delete mode, the rollback journal is deleted at the conclusion of each transaction.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.JournalMode.Memory
member.summary: The MEMORY journaling mode stores the rollback journal in volatile RAM. It may be used to reduce disk I/O but that decreases database safety and integrity. If the application using SQLite crashes in the middle of a transaction in this mode, the database file may become corrupt.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.JournalMode.Off
member.summary: In this mode rollback journal is completely disabled. The ROLLBACK command does not work; it behaves in an undefined way. Don't use the ROLLBACK command in this mode.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.JournalMode.Persist
member.summary: In the Persist mode rollback journal file is not deleted when the transaction is commited. Its first block filled with zeroes to prevent other connections rolling back from this journal. May optimize performance on platforms where deleting or truncating a file is much more expensive than overwriting the first block of a file with zeros.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.JournalMode.Truncate
member.summary: In the Truncate mode rollback journal file is truncated instead of deleting when the transaction is commited. May be used for gaining better performance, because on many systems, truncating a file is much faster than deleting the file.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.JournalMode.WAL
member.summary: In the WAL mode, Write-Ahead Logging is used instead of the standard rollback journal. This means that when database data is updated, the original content is preserved in the database file, and the changes are appended into a separate WAL file and eventually are transferred to the database.

member.name: T:Devart.Data.SQLite.LockingMode
member.summary: Determines whether the database is locked or not.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.LockingMode.Exclusive
member.summary: The database connection never releases file locks. The first time the database is read in exclusive mode, a shared lock is obtained and held. The first time the database is written, an exclusive lock is obtained and held.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.LockingMode.Normal
member.summary: The database connection unlocks the database file at the conclusion of each read or write transaction. This is the default behavior.

member.name: T:Devart.Data.SQLite.SQLiteTransactionMode
member.summary: Determines how the database is locked during transactions.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.SQLiteTransactionMode.Deferred
member.summary: No locks are acquired on the database until the database is first accessed. The first read operation against a database creates a shared lock and the first write operation creates a reserved lock. This is the default behavior.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.SQLiteTransactionMode.Exclusive
member.summary: An exclusive transaction causes exclusive locks to be acquired on all databases. No other thread or process will be able to read or write the database until the transaction is complete.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.SQLiteTransactionMode.Immediate
member.summary: Reserved locks are acquired on all databases without waiting for the database to be used. No other thread or process will be able to write to the database or initiate immediate or exclusive transactions. However, other processes can continue to read from the database.

member.name: T:Devart.Data.SQLite.SynchronizationMode
member.summary: Determines how the database is synchronized with writing to hard disk.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.SynchronizationMode.Full
member.summary: The database engine will pause at critical moments to make sure that data has actually been written to the disk surface before continuing.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.SynchronizationMode.Normal
member.summary: The database engine will still pause at the most critical moments, but less often than in Full mode. The Normal mode is faster than the Full mode. This is the default mode.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.SynchronizationMode.Off
member.summary: The database engine continues without pausing as soon as it has handed data off to the operating system. The database might become corrupted if the operating system crashes or the computer loses power. This is the fastest mode.

member.name: T:Devart.Data.SQLite.TempStoreMode
member.summary: Determines where temporary tables and indices are stored.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.TempStoreMode.Default
member.summary: The location of temporary data is defined by C preprocessor macro TEMP_STORE. Currently the generally available library stores temporary data in memory.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.TempStoreMode.File
member.summary: The temporary data is located in a file, in the directory specified by the property.

member.name: F:Devart.Data.SQLite.TempStoreMode.Memory
member.summary: The temporary data is located in memory.
